## Table of Contents

## Key terms

#### Displacement

The displacement of a point B from a point A is the shortest distance from A to B, together with the direction.

**Unit: m**

#### Speed

Distance travelled per unit time.

$$
\text{speed} = \frac{\text{distance travelled}}{\text{time taken}} = \frac{x}{t}
$$

**Unit: ms<sup>-1</sup>**

#### Velocity

Rate of change of displacement.

$$
\text{velocity} = \frac{\text{displacement}}{\text{time taken}} = \frac{x}{t}
$$

**Unit: ms<sup>-1</sup>**

#### Acceleration

Rate of change of velocity.

$$
\text{acceleration} = \frac{\text{change in velocity}}{\text{time taken}} = \frac{\Delta v}{t}
$$

**Unit ms<sup>-2</sup>**

In addtion, the words 'mean' and 'instantaneous' are applied to both speed and velocity.

- Mean is the average, measured over a significant ammount of time. For example, if calculated over a whole journey, velocity = total displacement / total time.
- Instantaneous is the speed or velocity at any one point in time, and is calculated by taking a very small interval (e.g. tangent on curve).

### Displacement-time graphs

<Callout emoji="⚡️">
  The gradient at any point gives a value for the velocity at that point.
</Callout>

</svg>

</div>

Hence, to calculate the **instantaneous** velocity at a point in time, we need to find the gradient of the tangent to the graph at that point. The instantaneous velocity at point B is:

$$
V_B = \text{gradient} = \frac{6-2}{2.3} = 1.74 \text{ ms}^{-1}
$$

To calculate the **average** velocity, we divide the change in displacement between those two points by the time between them. The average velocity between points $A$ and $C$ is:

$$
V_{AC} = \frac{\Delta x}{t} = \frac{5.1-3.5}{1.3} = 1.23 \text{ ms}^{-1}
$$

In a situation where the velocity is changing (i.e. a curve), it is very difficult to judge just by looking at it, whether the acceleration/deceleration is constant. It is useful to remember that if the acceleration is constant, the the displacement-time graph would be **parabolic** &mdash; i.e. $y=x^2$ or $y=-x^2$.

### Velocity-time

There are two rules for velocity-time graphs.

<Callout emoji="⚡️">
  The gradient of the velocity-time graph represents the acceleration
</Callout>

_If the line is curved, then to find the **instantaneous acceleration**, find the gradient of the **tangent** to the line at that point._

<Callout emoji="⚡️">
  The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement travelled.
</Callout>

The graph below shows an object accelerating from rest.

- In section $OA$, the object accelerations up to a velocity of 25 ms<sup>-1</sup>. The gradient is constant, so acceleration is constant.
- The gradient in section $AB$ is 0 &#8756; acceleration is 0 &mdash; i.e. constant velocity.
- In section $BC$, the object has constant deceleration.

The displacement in any section can be found by applying the second rule.

Area under $OA = 62.5$ m

Area under $AB = 125$ m

Area under $OA = 25$ m

## Equations for uniformly accelerated motion

This section relies upon the fact that we can assume the acceleration is constant. So, for example, when considering the motion of an object we must assume air-resistance is negligible. This approximation applies for many practical cases.

We can derive 4 equations for a body moving in a straight line with **uniform acceleration**.

The velocity of a body increases steadily from $u$ ms<sup>-1</sup> to $v$ ms<sup>-1</sup> in a time, $t$. The uniform acceleration, $a$, is given by

$$
\begin{align}
\text{acceleration} &= \frac{\text{change in velocity}}{\text{time taken}} \\
a &= \frac{v-u}{t} \\
at &= v-u \\
v&=u+at \text{ [Equation 1]}
\end{align}
$$

Since the velocity is increasing steadily, the average velocity will be given by

$$
\text{mean velocity} = \frac{u+v}{2}
$$

If $x$ is the displacement of the body in time, $t$, then

$$
\text{mean velocity} = \frac{x}{t}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\frac{x}{t}  = \frac{u+v}{2}
$$

and thus,

$$
x=\frac{1}{2}\left(u+v\right) t \text{ [Equation 2]}
$$

If $v=u+at$, then we can substitute this into equation 2.

$$
\begin{align}
x&=\frac{1}{2}\left(u+u+at\right) t \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left(2u+at\right) t \\
&= ut+ \frac{1}{2}at^2 \text{ [Equation 3]}
\end{align}
$$

For equation 4, we can use equation 1 to substitute $t$ for equation 2.

$$
\begin{align}
x&=\frac{\left(u+v\right)}{2} \times \frac{\left(v-u\right)}{a} \\
&= \frac{v^2-u^2}{2a} \\
2ax&= v^2-u^2 \\
v^2 &= u^2+2ax \text{ [Equation 4]}
\end{align}
$$

#### Notice that:

1. initial velocity, $u$, is in each equation
2. each equation has 4 of these 5 quantities &mdash; this means there is one quantity missing from each one.

## Falling objects

### Motion under gravity

A body falls because the force of **gravity** acts on it.

It is this force which causes the body to have a **weight**.

If there is no air resistance, then the body will fall with a **constant acceleration**.

Therefore, if there is no air resistance (e.g. on the Moon) or we can ignore air resistance, then we can apply the equations for uniformly accelerated motion to falling bodies.

On Earth (at sea level), the acceleration due to gravity $= g = 9.81$ ms<sup>-2</sup>.

### The effect of air resistance

When a body falls to the ground, there is usually a second force acting on it (as shown below). This is called air resistance.

As the body falls, it accelerates (i.e. its velocity increases).

As the velocity of the body increases, the size of the air resistance force also increases.

Eventually, the air resistance force becomes so large that it is equal to the weight of the body.

When this happens, the **two forces are balanced** and the body continues to fall at a **constant velocity**.

This constant velocity is called the **terminal velocity** of the falling body.

## Projectile motion

### Example 1

Consider a body which is moving horizontally at a steady speed and at the same time being accelerated vertically downwards due to gravity.

For example, a ball projected horizontally over the edge of a table.

The ball continues to move with the **same horizontal speed** while at the same time falling under the influence of gravity.

This ball takes the same time to reach the ground as a second identical ball simply dropped, and falling vertically, from the same height.

This shows that the horizontal motion of the first ball does not affect its vertical acceleration.

The **horizontal** and **vertical motions** of the ball can be treated separately.

Therefore, the **horizontal** and **vertica** motions are **independent** of each other.

### Example 2

Another example of projectile motion is the motion of a body projected at an angle to the horizontal.

For example, kicking a football or a rugby ball, throwing a discus or a javelin or throwing a cricket ball from one person to another.

The diagram shows a ball which has been kicked at an angle of 30&deg; to the horizontal.

We need to resolve the initial velocity into its **horizontal** and **vertical** components.

The horizontal and vertical motions can then be treated **independently**.

#### Note that:

1. since the horizontal motion is constant velocity motion, the only equation that you can use is $x=vt$.

2. since the vertical motion is uniformly accelerated motion (ignoring air resistance), you can use any of the SUVAT four equations.

### Worked example

_A projectile is fired from ground level with a velocity of 500 ms<sup>-1</sup> at 30&deg; to the horizontal. Calculate its horizontal range, the greatest height it reaches and the time taken to rise to that height. (Neglect air resistance.)_

<div className="flex justify-center mt-6">
  <svg
    width="479"
    height="146"
    viewBox="0 0 479 146"
    fill="none"
    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
  >
    <path

#### Horizontal motion

$u = 500\cos{30} = 433$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$v= 500\cos{30} = 433$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$a = 0$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$t = ?$, $x = ?$

#### Vertical motion (from $A$ to $B$)

$u = 500\sin{30} = 250$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$v = 0$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$a = - 9.81$ ms<sup>-1</sup>,

$t = ?$, $x = ?$

#### To find $t$ (use vertical motion):

$$
\begin{align}
v &= u + at\\
0 &= 250 + \left( -9.81 \times t \right)\\
9.81t&=250 \\
t &= 25.5 \text{ s}
\end{align}
$$

This is the time to reach the greatest height (point B).

To find the total time of flight we just need to double this. Therefore, time taken from $A \text{ to } C = 25.5 \times 2 = 51$ s.

#### To find the horizontal range (use horizontal motion):

$$
\begin{align}
x &=vt \\
&=433 \times 51 \\
&=22083 \text{ m} =22.1 \text{ km}
\end{align}
$$

#### To find the greatest height (use vertical motion):

$$
\begin{align}
x &= ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2 \\
&= \left( 250 \times 25.5 \right) + \frac{1}{2} \times -9.81 \times 25.5^2 \\
&= 6375 - 3189 \\
&= 3185 \text{ m}
\end{align}
$$
